title: Belgian princess among 1,300 arrested at Extinction Rebellion protest
text:
Princess Esmerelda was one of 1,307 people arrested during a week of climate change protests

A Belgian princess is among the more than 1,300 people arrested in London this week during mass climate change protests.

Princess Esmerelda, 63, said she was one of a number of demonstrators detained following a sit-in at Trafalgar Square on Thursday.

The princess, who is the daughter of the late Leopold III and his second wife Lilian Baels, Princess of Rethy, said she was questioned in the back of a police van and held for around five hours.

She tweeted afterwards: ‘Today along with many other protesters I was arrested and put in police custody. The climate emergency calls on all of us to put pressure on governments to act with urgency.’

Scotland Yard’s latest figures show 1,307 arrests have been made so far in connection with Extinction Rebellion protests in the capital this week.

Princess Esmerelda said she was detained following a sit-in at Trafalgar Square (Picture: Photonews)

She shared a photo of her ‘Released Under Investigation’ police paperwork

More than 100 healthcare professionals joined the sixth day of climate change protests in London on Saturday.

Doctors, nurses and medical students were among those demonstrating at Jubilee Gardens, near oil giant Shell’s London HQ, in the ‘Health March for the Planet’.

Several protesters leading the crowd wore hospital face masks, while others carried Extinction Rebellion flags and signs reading: ‘Climate change is a health issue.’

Doctors, nurses and medical students were among those demonstrating (Picture: Getty Images)

Several protesters leading the crowd wore hospital face masks to highlight air pollution (Picture: PA)

Caption: Doctors gather to protest in support of Extinction Rebellion at Jubilee Gardens (Picture: PA)

Protesters placed 180 pairs of shoes symbolising deaths due to pollution on the steps of Trafalgar Square (Picture: AFP)

Doctors held placards bearing slogans including ‘Climate change is a health emergency’ (Picture: Getty Images)

Alex Turner, 36, a paediatric and emergency doctor from Bristol who was wearing his blue scrubs and stethoscope, said: ‘We are meeting outside Shell because they are one of the biggest companies involved in the oil and energy industry, and they have real power to decarbonise that industry.

‘We are protesting illegal levels of air pollution.’

Another campaigner said raising awareness about the effects of climate change on health is part of their ‘duty of care as healthcare professionals’.

Earlier on Saturday, police arrested members of Animal Rebellion after they staged a demonstration at Billingsgate Fish Market in Poplar.
